chapter: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Identify the marked layer of the retina.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Identify the structure marked with red arrow185
questions.explanation: The marked structure in the slide is the outer plexiform layer of the retina.The outer plexiform layer (outer synaptic layer) is present between the outer nuclear layer and theinner nuclear layer. This layer stains lightly. This layer consists of the axons of rods and coneswhich synapse with dendrites of bipolar neurons and horizontal cells.200ILMNFLGCLIPL- INLMLMOPL- ONLELMPRPE
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: The distance of the fovea from the temporal margin of the optic disc is
questions.explanation: The distance of the fovea from the temporal margin of the optic disc is 2 disc diameters.The fovea is an excavation in the retinal surface at the center of the macula, with a diameter of 1.5mm, which is about the same as that of the optic disc. The foveola forms the bottom of the foveaand has a diameter of 0.35 mm. It is devoid of ganglion cells. The umbo is the central floor thefoveola, which corresponds to the foveolar light reflex. The foveal avascular zone (FAZ) is a centralarea (including foveola and surrounding areas) which contains no blood vessels but is surroundedby a continuous network of capillaries.The macula is a round area at the posterior pole, lying inside the temporal vascular arcades. Itmeasures 5.5 mm in diameter. The inner layers of the macula contain the yellow xanthophyllcarotenoid pigments lutein and zeaxanthin in far higher concentrations than the peripheral retina(hence, the full name "macula lutea", which means yellow plaque).MaculaLuteaFoveaCentralisArteryOptic nerveOptic diskPeripheral RetinaVein201
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Causes for expanding blind spot are all except
questions.explanation: Optic disc hypoplasia does not cause enlargement of the blind spot.The physiological blind spot is an area of absolute scotoma in the visual field, seen in the region ofoptic disc. It is due to the absence of photoreceptors (rods and cones) in that region. Enlargedblind spot is seen in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) (Option A), papilledema (Option C),medullated nerve fibers (Option D), optic disc drusen, coloboma of optic disc andmyopic disc with a crescent.Optic nerve hypoplasia is the most common congenital optic disc anomaly. There isunderdevelopment of the optic disc in the disease and it typically presents with a small disc that issurrounded by a yellowish pigmented ring, called the 'double ring sign'.Option A: In primary open-angle glaucoma(POAG), the optic disc enlargement is seen secondaryto increased intra-ocular pressure (IOP) in the eye.Option C: Papilledema is a passive disc swelling seen with raised intracranial pressure. The blindspot is enlarged due to the edema of the optic disc.Option D: Medullated or opaque nerve fibers are the abnormal myelination of nerve fibers of theretina. Normally, optic nerve myelination stops at the level of lamina cribrosa. If the myelinationcontinues beyond the optic disc it leads to the expansion of the blind spot. On ophthalmoscopicexamination, these are seen as a whitish patch with feathery margins.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Which statement regarding Müller cells is false?

options.B: Their nuclei lie in the outer nuclear layer
options.C: Their foot processes form the inner & outer limiting membranes
options.D: They contribute to inner blood retinal barrier

questions.explanation: The nuclei of Müller cells lie in the inner nuclear layer.Müller cells are a type of macroglial cells of the retina. The human retina contains 8–10 millionMüller cells. Their nuclei lie in the inner nuclear layer and their processes extend across theretinal layers to form the inner and outer limiting membranes. Their functions include:1. Providing structural stability to the retinal2. Interacting with other neurons and their functional and metabolic support3. Providing neurons with trophic substances and removing metabolic waste4. Playing a critical role in regulating the extracellular space volume as well as ion and waterhomeostasis and in maintaining the inner blood-retinal barrierAstrocytes are another type of macroglial cells of the retina. They play a crucial role in retinalvascularization. In the mature retina, they are restricted to the nerve fiber and ganglion celllayers.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the development of retinal vasculature?

options.A: Grow to temporal ora by 34 weeks of gestation
options.B: Grow to nasal ora by 36 weeks of gestation
options.C: Originate from mesenchymal tissue during week 16 of gestation

questions.explanation: 202Retinal vessels reach temporal ora at approximately 40 weeks of gestation.Retinal vessels develop de novo from mesenchymal tissue, beginning during the 4th month ofgestation. They radiate outward (centrifugally) from the optic nerve, reaching the nasal ora by 36weeks.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A preterm baby treated for respiratory distress syndrome is found to have white pupillaryreflex on opthalmologic examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A preterm baby, treated for respiratory distress syndrome, with leucocoria (white pupillary reflex)most likely has retrolental fibroplasia.Retrolental fibroplasia, also known as retinopathy of prematurity, is a proliferative retinopathy.Risk factors include prematurity, very low birth weight and supplemental oxygen therapy (givenfor respiratory distress syndrome). ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may leadto blindness in serious cases.RotnopathyRoʻrotontal> PVAARRROOF WurROP)FIDroplaolaRetinopathy of prematurity (ROP)Edema of corneaTearingWhite masspresses on lensStage 5Retinopathy Retrolental FibroplasiaOMARROW203Pale fetal irisW
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Which of the following is included under threshold disease when screening neonates forretinopathy of prematurity?

options.A: ROP stage 1 extending from 6'o clock to 11'0 clock in zone 1 with plus disease
options.B: ROP stage 3 extending from 2'0 clock to 7'o clock in zone 2 with plus disease
options.C: ROP stage 3 extending from 1'o clock to 4'o clock in zone 1 without plus disease
options.D: ROP stage 2 extending from 3'o clock to 6'o clock in zone 2 with plus disease187

questions.explanation: ROP stage 3 extending from 2'0 clock to 7'0 clock (6 clock hours) in zone 2 with plus disease fitsinto the definition of threshold disease.Threshold disease of retinopathy of prematurity is defined by the CRYO-ROP study as:•Stage 3 disease: Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous• Involvement of zones 1 or 2•• Involvement of either at least 5 contiguous (continuous) clock hours or 8 non-contiguous clockhours.Associated with "plus disease": Dilatation and tortuosity of posterior pole vessels in at least twoquadrants at the posterior pole.Treatment of threshold disease is laser photocoagulation of the involved part within 72 hours ofdiagnosis.Management of retinopathy of prematurityIdentification of HIGH RISK casesPreterm infants born 34 weeks of gestational ageBirth weight 1750 gramsPreterm infants 34-36 weeks of age withrisk factors (prolonged oxygen therapy,respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis)Infants born 28 weeks1200 gramsSCREENINGInfants born 28 weeks1200 gramsScreen first within 2-3 weeks ofnological age/birthScreen first after 4 weeks ofchronologicalchTREATMENT when is it recommendedThreshold diseaseAtleast 5 contiguous or a cumulativenoncontiguous clock hours ofstage 3 ROP in zone 1/zone 2 in presence of plus disease(defined by CRYO-ROP study)Zone 1Pre-threshold type 1 ROPZone 1. any Stage.plus diseaseZone 1. Stage 3Zone 2. Stage 2/3.plus disease(defined by ETROP study)PLUS disease: refers to venousdilatation and arteriolar tortuosity atposterior pole in at least 2 quadrantsHow to treatLaser photocoagulation of the entire avascular retina upto ora serrata(Diode-red laser: 810 nm wavele gth is preferredby lens sparing PPV for Tractional RD)These guidelines are recommended by APOMARROWTreatment of the various stages of ROP includes:• Pre-threshold type 1 disease - Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours and is done bylaser photocoagulation of avascular retina.• Pre-threshold type 2 disease (Any ROP not following under type 1)- Observation for progression• Threshold disease - Laser photocoagulation of avascular retina•Aggresive posterior-ROP- Intravitreal anti-VEGF agents, eg., bevacizumab• Tractional retinal detachment (stage 4A) - Pars plana vitrectomy204
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: All of the following are true statements regarding retinopathy of prematurity except:

options.A: First screening should be done 32 weeks PMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later
options.B: For infants less than 28 week, screen at 3 week of postnatal age to detect APROP
options.C: Neonates are best examined at ophthalmology OPD and hence should be transported
options.D: Screening is done using indirect ophthalmoscopy by an expert ophthalmologist

questions.explanation: Neonates are best examined in the neonatal unit itself under the supervision of the attendingneonatologist. It is not recommended to transport infants to the ophthalmic outpatientdepartment for examination.The first screening examination should be carried out by indirect ophthalmoscopy at 32 weeksPMA or 4 weeks PNA, whichever is later. For infants born at less than 28 weeks, screening is doneat 3 weeks PNA to detect APROP. Aggressive posterior ROP ("rush" disease, AP-ROP), ifuntreated, usually progresses to total retinal detachment (stage 5) within a few days. It ischaracterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease and ill-defined nature of theretinopathy.Management of retinopathy of prematurityIdentification of HIGH RISK casosPreterm infants born 34 weeks of gestational ageBirth weight 1750 gramsPreterm infants 34-36 weeks of age withrisk factors (prolonged oxygen therapy,respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis)Infants born 26 weeksand1200 gramsScreen first after 4 weeks ofchronological age/birthSCREENINGTREATMENT when is it recommendedThreshold diseaseAtleast 5 contiguous or a cumulativenoncontiguous clock hours ofstage 3 ROP in zone 1/zone 2 in presence of plus disease(defined by CRYO-ROP study)Infants born 28 weeksor1200 GramsScreen first within 2-3 weeks ofchronological age/birthPre-threshold type 1 ROPZone 1. any Stage.plus diseaseZone 1. Stage 3Zone 2. Stage 2/3.plus disease(defined by ETROP study)PLUS disease: refers to venousdilatation and arteriolar tortuosity atposterior pole in at least 2 quadrantsHow to treatLaser photocoagulation of the entire avascular retina upto ora serrata(Diode-red laser: 810 nm wavelength in preferredby lens sparing PPV for Tractional RD)These guidelines are recommended by IAPOMARROW
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A preterm neonate admitted to NICU who received supplemental oxygen is being screenedfor retinopathy of prematurity. Fundus examination reveals a subtotal retinal detachment.How will you stage the disease?
questions.explanation: Subtotal retinal detachment is considered to be stage 4 of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).The clinical staging of ROP is as follows:•Stage 1 - Formation of a demarcation line at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from theavascular retina.•.•Stage 2- Formation of an intraretinal ridgeStage 3- Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreousStage 4- Subtotal retinal detachment•Stage 5- Total retinal detachment205RotnopathstocoSU sa maFluid in aanname€29 ROPRotroismal*<C>> EVARRO® JunurROP)
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 14-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distresssyndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks fromnow would you schedule the screening?
questions.explanation: In the scenario above, the postnatal age of the premature infant is 2 weeks, and therefore, theinfant must be screened in 2 weeks i.e., 4 weeks of postnatal age, as per the guidelines for themanagement of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).ROP guidelines state that the first examination should be performed between 4 and 6 weeks ofpostnatal age (after birth) or between 31-33 weeks of post-conceptional age (calculated asgestational age + postnatal age), whichever is later. Ideally, 2 examinations must be performed;however, 1 may suffice if it shows complete retinal vascularisation.Management of retinopathy of prematurityIdentification of HIGH RISK casesPreterm infants born 34 weeks of gestational ageBirth weight 1750 gramsPreterm infants 34-36 weeks of age withrisk factors (prolonged oxygen therapy.respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis)Infantsborn 28 weeksand a 1200 gramsScreen first after 4 weeks ofchronological age/birthSCREENINGRTREATMENT when is it recommendedThreshold diseaseAtleast 5 contiguous or 8 cumulativenoncontiguous clock hours ofstage 3 ROP in zone 1/zone 2 in presence of plus disease(defined by CRYO-ROP study)Infants born 28 weeksor1200 GramsScreen first within 2-3 weeks ofchronological age/birth10Zone 1Pre-threshold type 1 ROPZone 1. any Stage.plus diseaseZone 1. Stage 3Zone 2. Stage 2/3.plus disease(defined by ETROP study)OptioPLUS disease: refers to venousdilatation and arteriolar tortuosity atposterior pole in at least 2 quadrantsHow to treatLaser photocoagulation of the entire avascular retina upto ora serrata(Diode-red laser: 810 nm wavelength in preferredby lens sparing PPV for Tractional RD)These guidelines are recommended by IAPOMARROW
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Which of the following is the most important factor for the development of diabeticretinopathy?
questions.explanation: 206The most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy is the duration of diabetes.Diabetic retinopathy constitutes the retinal changes seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.The most important factor for its development is duration of diabetes after the onset of puberty,followed by glycemic control. It is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus. The presence ofhypertension increases the risk of diabetic retinopathy.First fundus examination for type 1 diabetes is done after 5 years after diagnosis and for type 2 isdone at the time of diagnosis. The frequency of follow-up for types 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus isevery year. Diabetes in pregnancy is followed up every 3 months.The earliest feature of diabetic retinopathy is microaneurysms, which are present in the innernuclear layer of the retina.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Which of the following findings on a fundus examination would suggest severenon-proliferative diabetic retinopathy?

options.A: Significant venous beading in any of the 4 quadrants

questions.explanation: Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants is a feature of severe NPDR.Note: Macular star is a feature of malignant hypertensive retinopathy.Cotton woolspotsA Grosso (Br J Ophthalmol, 2005)
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend adilated fundus examination for him?

options.D: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.explanation: A 45 year old diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is likely to have type 2 diabetes and thus, he shouldundergo screening for diabetic retinopathy immediately.Duration of diabetes is the most important risk factor for developing diabetic retinopathy,especially proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The recommendations for first fundus examination indiabetic retinopathy is:• Within 3-5 years of diagnosis in type 1 diabetes• Immediately in type 2 diabetes.207Later, the screening is continued once every year in both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes. In the eventproliferative diabetic retinopathy develops, screening is done more frequently - once every 2months.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: ETDRS study was related to?
questions.explanation: Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a randomized clinical trial that studiedthe effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.The results of the study demonstrated the beneficial effects of focal photocoagulation on diabeticmacular edema. The study resulted in the recommendation that all eyes with clinically significantdiabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescentangiography (FF

options.A: to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shownbelow, which is characteristic of:189a) Macular ischemia

questions.explanation: The fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) image shows enlarged foveal avascular zone, seen as ahypofluorescent patch in the macula (white arrow), with surrounding capillary non perfused areas(blue arrow). Both of these are suggestive of macular ischemia.The above mentioned findings when combined with the history of diabetes in this patient pointstowards the diagnosis of diabetic macular ischemia.FFA images in a case of diabetic retinopathy are given below:• Non proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)• Punctate or pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence - microaneurysms• Abnormal branching of arteriovenous shunt - intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)•Patchy filling defects of ischemia due to capillary atrophy or non perfusion208• Increase in the size of hypoperfusion in foveal avascular zone in macular ischemia2. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy(PDR)• Fluorescein leakage - in retinal neovascularization.• Leakage in the disc region suggests neovascularization of the disc (NVD) and leakage in otherregions suggests neovascularization elsewhere (NVE).The image below shows pinpoint areas of hyperfluorescence and areas of fluorescein leakage inthe fundus.10/7/2019, 00FAO 50.41 55 ART(33) peOption B: Macular edema also known as cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluidbetween the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina following a break in theblood-retina barrier. On fundoscopy, a honeycomb appearance is seen, and on FFA, flower petalpattern can be seen. The below image shows the flower petal pattern on FFA as seen in CME.209Option C: Submacular hemorrhage also known as subretinal hemorrhage will obscure thechoroidal dye visualization and appaers as ill defined areas of hypoperfusion in the correspondingarea. The retinal vessels overlying the area would, however will be visualized. There are noassosciated features of pinpoint hyperfluorescence and vascular leakage that are usually seen withdiabetic macular ischemia. The below given images show fluorescein angiography which revealblocked fluorescence in the maculae of both eyes due to subretinal hemorrhages.Option D: Premacular hemorrhage is a term used to define vitreous hemorrhage that occurs in thesubhyaloid space. It is seen as a region of hypofluorescence with no overlying retinal vasculaturevisualization on FFA.b
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 69-year-old patient with hypertension has silver wiring, papilledema, and arteriovenousnipping visible on fundoscopy, but no other changes. How would you grade his disease?
questions.explanation: 210A patient with hypertension having "silver wiring," papilledema, and arteriovenous nipping visibleon fundoscopy has Grade IV retinopathy.AGunn's sianrtensive retinopathyNormal AV crossingCopperArteriole thickened.narrowed andnarrowingHypertensive retinopathy grade 3Hypertensive retinopathy grade 4OMARROWCotton woolsuperficialHard exudatesmarginsMacular storHard exudates.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 40-year-old male, newly diagnosed with systolic hypertension, presents with a three-weekhistory of bilateral blurry vision. His visual acuity is 20/30 and 20/120 in the right and lefteye, respectively. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the followingfindings is least likely to be seen on his fundoscopy?
questions.explanation: Systolic hypertension (systolic blood pressure over 200 mm Hg) with bilateral blurry vision andunremarkable examination findings point to a diagnosis of hypertensive retinopathy. Intra-retinalmicrovascular abnormalities (IRMA) are not seen in hypertensive retinopathy. IRMA is a featureof diabetic retinopathy.Arteriolar narrowing occurs due to vasoconstriction and sclerosis of retinal vessels due tohypertension. Cotton wool spots are areas of nerve fibre layer infarcts. They occur due to capillaryobliteration in hypertension.Hypertensive retinopathyGunn's signMCONormal AV crossingCopperArteriole thickened.narrowed andBonnet's signHypertensive retinopathy grade 3Hypertensive retinopathy grade 4OMARROW211Cotton woolhaemorrhageHard exudatesmarginsMacular stor
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: The following image shows the picture of the fundus in a patient taken 48 hours aftersustaining severe head trauma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The image shows multiple cotton wool spots around the disc. This is Purtschers'retinopathy, which is classically associated with severe head injury.It is also seen in pancreatitis and chest trauma due to fat/air embolism. Ophthalmoscopy revealsmultiple, variably sized cotton-wool spots and intraretinal hemorrhages around the optic nerve.There is no effective treatment.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true regarding sickle cell retinopathy?

options.A: Sea-fan appearance is seen in supero-temporal quadrant.
options.B: HbSS has more severe ocular manifestations than HbSC.
options.D: Central retinal vein occlusion may be seen.

questions.explanation: Hemoglobin SC and S-Thal disease have the most severe ocular manifestations, although sickle SSdisease has the most severe systemic manifestations.The incidence of proliferative retinopathy in SC disease (Hb SC) is 33%, sickle cell thalassemia(Hb S-Thal) is 14%, SS disease (Hb SS) is 3%. In sickle cell retinopathy, elevated blood viscositymay occlude venules and arterioles, as well as capillaries. The following fundus findings can benoted as a result:• Retinal vascular peripheral non-perfusion•• Retinal hemorrhages: "salmon patches," "iridescent spots," and "black sunbursts" are hallmarksof nonproliferative sickle cell retinopathy.• Peripheral retinal neovascularization in a "sea fan" configuration is the hallmark of proliferativesickle cell retinopathy. They are also described as "parachute" lesions. They are most commonlyfound in the supero-temporal vascular arcades.•Angioid streaks (Rupture of Bruch's membrane)Conjunctival "comma-shaped" capillaries and iris atrophy are other ocular findings seen.Complications of sickle cell retinopathy include central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) (occurs dueto retinal hypoxia), vitreous hemorrhage and tractional retinal detachment.The image below shows 'sea fans' as seen on fluorescein angiography.212
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Roth spots are seen in191
questions.explanation: Roth's spots are seen in acute leukemia.Roth's spots are retinal hemorrhages with white or pale center. The white centre due to coagulatedfibrin-platelet plug is surrounded by red rim that is caused by hemorrhage. Roth's spots may beseen in:•Subacute bacterial endocarditis• Leukemia• Diabetes• Sickle cell retinopathy• HIV retinopathy•Hypertensive retinopathy•Systemic lupus erythematosusThe fundus image below shows Roth's spots.213DAILY ROUNDSOption B: Uveal melanoma devolps due to malignant transformation of the normal melanocytespresent in the uveal tissue. Primary posterior uveal melanoma (choroidal melanoma) which formsthe majority of uveal melanoma manifests as:•• A solitary elevated subretinal grey-brown dome shaped mass• "Collar stud" appearance on B-scan - when the tumor breaks through the Bruchs membrane andprotrudes into subretinal space•• "Double circulation" signPrimary anterior uveal melanoma frequently involves the iris and presents as nodular melanocyticmass on the iris. The below given fundus image shows the "double circulation sign" of choroidalmelanoma.Option C: Uveal lymphoma is characterized by localized or diffuse uveal infiltrates of malignantlymphoma cells. Fundus examination in these patients show diffuse creamy thickening ofposterior uvea with nodular accentuation.214
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy presents with 6/6 vision in the right eye and vision for only hand movementsin the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. The left eye shows retinaldetachment, subretinal yellowish exudates, and telangiectatic vessels. What is the mostprobable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Unilateral decreased vision with retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates andtelangiectatic vessels in a young boy points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.Coats' disease, described by Coats in 1908, affects boys three times more often than girls, has noreported racial or ethnic predilection, and is usually unilateral. The average age at diagnosis is8–16 years. The clinical course is generally progressive.It is characterized by discrete zones of retinal vascular abnormalities like aneurysmal dilatationand leakage. It is associated with localized lipid deposition (hard exudates) and varying degrees ofsubretinal exudates. Vessels may appear telangiectatic, and they may have aneurysms that aregrape-like, clustered, or light bulb-shaped.The image below depicts the typical vascular abnormalities with aneurysmal dilatation,telangiectasia, exudation, and severe lipid deposition in the macula which are seen in Coat'sdisease.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 64-year-old female presented with complaints of blurring of vision and pain in her left eye.She also gave a history of redness in her left eye about 3 months back, which she passed off asnormal conjunctivitis. On tonometry, the IOP is 55 mm Hg. The slit-lamp revealed rubeosisiridis in all four quadrants. The fundus picture of the patient is given below. What is the mostprobable diagnosis?192
questions.explanation: Monocular blurring of vision and pain with "splashed sauce" appearance on fundoscopy points.towards a diagnosis of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterised by sudden visual loss. There issplashed sauce appearance on fundoscopy due to retinal hemorrhages. Risk factors include highintraocular pressure (IOP), hypertension and blood viscosity syndromes.Its complications include neovascularisation of the iris (rubeosis iridis) and neovascular glaucoma(NVG). NVG typically occurs 3 months after the occlusive event. Up to 50% of eyes develop NVGfollowing ischaemic CRVO. Pan-retinal photocoagulation is the treatment of choice.215CRVO is classified into two types:• Ischemic CRVO: Characterized by relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), markedly reducedvisual acuity, and many cotton-wool spots• Non-ischemic CRVO: Characterized by normal pupillary reaction, reduced visual acuity, and fewcotton-wool spotsTreatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A man with history of hypertension and loss of vision in the left eye has the followingfundoscopy findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The image above demonstrates characteristic flame-shaped hemorrhages, localized to thesuperotemporal sector of the retina. The image, along with loss of vision and history ofhypertension, points to a diagnosis of branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO), specificallyaffecting the superotemporal branch of the retinal vein.Occlusion of a single branch of the retinal vein leads to branched retinal vein occlusion. Thisocclusion leads to impaired venous drainage, resulting in the accumulation of blood within theretina. The visual defect in BRVO tends to be partial.Note: The different types of retinal vascular obstructions are branched retinal vein obstruction(BRVO), central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO), branched retinal artery obstruction (BRAO) andcentral retinal artery obstruction (CRAO). Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is the second mostcommon retinal vascular disorder after diabetic retinopathy.In CRVO, tortuosity and engorgement of all branches of the central retinal vein are seen, affectingall quadrants of the retina.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss inhis left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored. Onphysical exam, a carotid bruit is heard and a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted onocular examination. His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following is the bestimmediate step in the management of this condition?193
questions.explanation: Sudden painless unilateral vision loss with carotid bruit (carotid artery disease) and the funduspicture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Thebest immediate step in management is ocular massage among the given options.Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the levelof lamina cribrosa. Risk factors include heart disease, carotid artery disease, mucormycosis,varicella infection, radiation exposure and trauma. It may be caused by the following:Emboli of carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboliare cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli• Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis• Retinal arteritis with obliteration•Angiospasm• Raised intraocular pressure• Thrombophilic disorders216Patients often present with sudden painless monocular loss of vision with history of a similarepisode that resolved spontaneously (amaurosis fugax). On examination, direct pupillary reflex isabsent and relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive. Fundus examination showsmarked attenuation of arteries (thread like arteries), interrupted blood flow in vein (cattletrack appearance), cherry red spot, severe edema and retinal pallor.A cherry-red spot of the macula is typical and arises in this area because of the absence ofganglion cells at the foveola resulting in the transmission of the normal choroidal color. This incontrast to the surrounding area where intense retinal whitening blocks the transmission of thenormal choroidal color.Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by IV acetazolamide or ocularmassage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment optionsinclude IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photodisruption in somecases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 52-year-old woman presents with complaints of sudden painless loss of vision in the left eyesince yesterday. She also gives a history of temporal headaches, myalgias, and pain in the jawwhile chewing. Examination of the left eye reveals a visual acuity of HM+ and an RAPD.Fundus examination of the left eye shows cattle trucking of blood within the retinal veins onapplying gentle pressure. Which of the following is the likely cause of fundal findings?
questions.explanation: A 52-year-old woman temporal headaches, myalgias and pain in the jaw while chewing likely hasgiant cell arteritis (GCA). Given that she has sudden painless monocular loss of vision with RAPDand points to a diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).GCA is the most common primary vasculitis in adults. It is a risk factor for the development ofCRAO. CRAO occurs due to obstruction of the retinal artery at the level of lamina cribrosa. Whenobstruction to the blood flow is not complete, the flow may be partially restored. Thus, gentlepressure upon the globe may break the column of venous blood into red beads separated by clearinterspaces. This gives the characteristic 'cattle truck' appearance.Option A: Ischemic CRVO shows a characteristic "splashed tomato sauce" appearance onfundoscopy.Option C: Non-Ischemic CRVO does not present with such a severe loss of visual acuity.Option D: Branched retinal artery occlusion presents with hemifield visual defects.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden painless loss of vision. Fundoscopy findings areshown below. Which of the following findings do you expect in this patient?194
questions.explanation: Sudden painless monocular loss of vision with fundoscopy showing Hollehorstplaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Relative afferent pupillary defect isseen in these cases.Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundusexamination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinalvessels.Note: Although elevated intraocular pressure has been implicated as a cause of central retinalartery obstruction, it is unlikely that intraocular pressure can be raised high enough to blockarterial inflow to the eye217R(affected)Marcus-Gunn PupilOMARROWL(normal)
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describesthe sensation that a curtain was coming up over his affected eye. In addition, 7 days ago thepatient noticed what he described as flashing lights and floaters. He gives a history of havingcataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. A B-scan image of his left eye is shown below.Which of the following statements best describes the pathology?195

options.B: Fibrovascular membranes in the vitreous causing traction
options.C: Fluid accumulation between NSR and RPE due to retinal tear
options.D: Fluid accumulation between NSR and RPE due to choroidal exudation

questions.explanation: The prodromal symptoms of flashing lights, floaters followed by loss of monocular vision (curtainover the eye) and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between NSR andRPE due to a retinal tear.Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigmentepithelium. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the most common type of retinal detachment.It occurs due to fluid accumulation after a retinal break (tear). High myopia, trauma,pseudophakia, aphakia are predisposing factors. Patients present with photopsia (flashes of lightdue to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break), floaters and visual field defect (blackcurtain/veil in front of the eye).Signs include hypotony, as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through theRPE and Shafers sign or tobacco dusting (pigments in the anterior vitreous). The detached retinais convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations. The most dangerous typeof retinal break is horseshoe tear and the most dangerous location of retinal break is thesupero-temporal retina.Treatment is by prophylactic laser barrage, scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy and pars planavitrectomy.Other types of retinal detachment are tractional and exudative type:Tractional retinal detachment occurs when fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due tolong-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. It is seen in proliferativediabetic retinopathy, central retinal venous occlusion, Eales disease and ROP. The detached retinais concave in configuration. No breaks are seen. Treatment is with pars plana vitrectomy withendo photocoagulation.Exudative retinal detachment is seen when exudative fluid from the choroid collects in thesubretinal space. Patients present with visual field defects, floaters due to vitritis but no218photopsia. The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break isseen. Shifting fluid is seen.The image below shows a fundus which reveals retinal detachment inferiorly from 3-9 o'clock withtear at 3:30.Retinal DetachmentOMARROW
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Pneumatic retinopexy is an outpatient procedure where retinal detachment is sealed with airinsufflation. Which of the following gases would you use while performing the saidprocedure?
questions.explanation: Sulphur hexafluoride is the gas used in pneumatic retinopexy for the treatment of retinaldetachmentsPneumatic retinopexy is used for the treatment of fresh retinal detachments with a single retinalbreak in the superior two-thirds of the fundus. In this procedure, a bubble is injected intravitreallythrough the conjunctiva and postoperatively the patient is positioned so that the bubbletamponades the retinal break against the retinal pigment epithelium.Single/clusterof breaks withshallow retinaldetachmentSuperiorApproach to the managementof a retinal detachmentRetina mobileInferiorLocate retinal breaksBullousretinaldetachmentPneumo-retinopexyCryotherapyFailureexternalbuckleSubretinalfluid persistsConventinalsurgery forrotinal detachment(cryotherapy, externalbuckle, encirclage andsubretinal fluid drainage)PeripheralvitreoustractionRetinal mobilitycompromisedProliferativevitreoretinopathy/tractionextensive vitreousVitreoretinal procedure(vitretomy, membrane peeling.internal subretinalfluid damage)RetinaflatGastamponade©MARROW219Retina notflattenedSilicone oil.perfluorocarbons,liquids, tamponadeEndolaser
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: A 24-year-old woman who is 8 months pregnant, myopic, and diabetic presents to you withsudden painless loss of vision in her right eye. She is a known case of Eales' disease. Herblood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. Which of her conditions is responsible for a fundus findingof retinal detachment with a positive shifting fluid sign?
questions.explanation: Exudative retinal detachment is characterized by positive shifting fluid sign. Among herconditions, toxemia of pregnancy is one of the causes of exudative retinal detachment.Exudative retinal detachment occurs due to the presence of subretinal fluid in the absence of tearor traction. It is caused by:•Malignant melanoma of the choroid• RetinoblastomaVogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) syndrome.• Uveal effusion syndrome•Posterior scleritis•Coat's disease• Malignant hypertension•Pregnancy-induced hypertensive retinopathy•Sympathetic ophthalmitisPatients present with sudden and painless diminution of vision, visual field defects and grey reflex(detached retina looks grey). Indirect ophthalmoscopy is the investigation of choice.The image depicts retinal detachment showing a smooth, detached convex retina with subretinalfluid.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Shifting fluid sign is seen in?
questions.explanation: 220The presence of shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.In serous retinal detachment, there is a subretinal accumulation of the serous fluid mostly dueto the breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier. When the position of the head is altered, the fluidshifts to the dependent portion. Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration. Aretinal tear or preretinal traction is absent.Other options:Option B: Traction RD has a concave configuration and breaks are absent. Retinal mobility isseverely reduced and shifting fluid is absent.Option C: Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous with substantialvitreous blood or inflammatory cells. Retinal breaks are also seen.
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Hollenhorst plaques are seen in
questions.explanation: Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAO).They are cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. They originate from atherosclerotis plaquesin larger arteries. The image below shows Hollenhorst plaques (arrow).
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: Identify the condition.
questions.explanation: The above image shows a loss of foveal reflex and central serous retinopathy, therefore showingfocal foveal detachment.There is oedema at the fovea signifying foveal detachment from underlying retinal pigmentepithelium. Macular oedema is also present (grey dull retina with a ring reflex around the site ofoedema). Thus, the most appropriate choice would be foveal detachment.221Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in themacular region. It occurs due to increased permeability of choriocapillaris, leading to fluidaccumulation in the subretinal space. Therefore, it is now known as centralserous choriopathy (CSC).If there is serous retinal detachment at macula, there is sudden painless loss of vision. Patientsalso have relative positive scotoma, micropsia and metamorphopsia. On ophthalmoscopy, acircular ring reflex present. The foveal reflex is absent. On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA),an enlarging ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern is seen.Treatment is generally not required. It is usually self-limiting, but often recurrent. Steroids arecontraindicated.DAILYROUNDS
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is the given sign seen?197DAILY ROUNDSC
questions.explanation: The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showing an enlarging ink-blotpattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Smokestackappearance is another pattern of fundus seen in CSR and is a characteristic sign of this condition.Amsler grid is used for:• Assess macular function and detecting maculopathy.• Evaluate the visual field of 10°Good for follow-up in CSR222Amsler GridOMARROW
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment

questions.question: The ETDRS chart is used for visual evaluation in diabetic patients. What does ETDRS standfor?

options.A: Extended treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
options.B: Early treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
options.C: Emergency treatment for diabetic retinopathy study
options.D: Emerging treatment for diabetic retinopathy study

questions.explanation: ETDRS stands for Early Treatment for Diabetic Retinopathy Study.ETDRS was a clinical trial designed to evaluate if argon laser photocoagulation or aspirintreatment can reduce the risk of visual loss or slow the progression of diabetic retinopathy inpatients with mild-to-severe nonproliferative or early proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Duringthe study, three new visual acuity charts were created in place of Snellen's visual chart.223
questions.chapter_heading: Retinal vascular disorders and Retinal detachment
